bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, April 20, 1953

div1.p: Hench will send Truby copies of the checks in Kean's checking account, as well as the checkbook itself, so that Truby can estimate Camp Lazear's expenses.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, April 20, 1953
div1.opener:
April 20, 1953
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I am still head over heels with my long and very difficult paper, working far
into the night. However my secretary has kindly made for us a typewritten
record of all the checks in Major Kean's checking account. I think these will
be very useful to you as they will tell you something about what the money was
spent for and so on. I am sending you herewith three copies of the account,
thinking you might want to have some correspondence with someone and perhaps
actually show the account. If you want more, we can easily make another ozalid
copy.

You will note that we have copied the items as Major Kean wrote them, even
though we know some of the spellings are wrong. For example, check No. 25,
was for Niconar Fernandez, which Major Kean spelled Nicomar. Check No. 26
should have been for John R. Kissinger instead of John J., etc. In other words,
this represents as faithful a record of the actual check stubs as we could make
it, interpreting his handwriting.

Because there is nothing like actually seeing the check book, I am taking a chance
on the U. S. mails and sending you the actual check book by separate registered
mail. I am sure that nothing will happen to it in your careful hands and I
would appreciate it if you would return it to me eventually also by registered
mail.

In your recent letter you seem to have that that maybe Reed received $40,000
from General wood. I am writing this without reference to my yellow fever data
but off-hand I thought he only received $10,000. Wasn't that amount mentioned
in General Kean's description of his visit to General Wood with Major Reed - the
description given in Kean's address at the dedication of Reed's birthplace, but
you may be correct in this amount. I have never come across any accounting made
by Reed himself for any more money and wondered whether $10,000 had been promised
but actually only $6,635.50 was used as per the enclosed account. I haven't
checked to see whether the payments to all of the volunteers are accounted for
here and it may well be that Reed had a separate account; however I doubt it as
Kean's seems to begin with the opening of the camp and ends after the camp was
finally given up.

It was my impression from Johnny Moran that the Reed buildings were constructed
by soldiers in the Engineering Corps from Camp Columbia and this may well be so
as at least one of the buildings was ready for occupancy late in November and
General Albert E. Truby
- 2 -
April 20, 1953
if it was built by civilians paid for by the army, we don't have the account or,
if it was built by soldiers, we have no record. In any event, notice the checks
for carpentry service in December.

Some of the most costs for the camp seem extremely low. I don't know whether they
represent extra meat or the rest being gotten from the Quartermaster Corps or
whether all of the camp expenses are listed here. I would certainly suspect
that the grocery items here listed were extras and did not represent the entire
grocery expense for the camp personnel, but of that you will know more.

Do you have any idea what the small checks on January 3 to various volunteers
were for - checks for $22 and $24 or less? Do you suppose it was like that for
Gust Lambert, Check No. 30, for extra services as laborers or were they per-
haps paid for clerical services, although Moran seems to have been the one who
got that pay.
Check No. 70 is interesting and inexplicable to me.

The deposit of September 9 of $100 I understand. Reed and others had intended
to release the camp earlier and then in one of Reed's letters which I have, he
wrote, I think from Washington, to Wood or perhaps to Kean (I have the letter
at home) and asked him to continue the rent of the camp through the summer with
the possibility that they might use it again. Therefore Major Kean had to get
another $100 of which he spent $60.

Should you wish to send the extra copy to Mr. Hanberry, he might be able to
help and I don't know whether or not Mr. Tate would be able to help.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
